{{DISPLAYTITLE:Greenpeace ''Arctic Sunrise'' ship case}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2013}} [[File:Arctic Sunrise in Libya 1.jpg|{{largethumb}}|The ''[[Arctic Sunrise]]'' in 2007.]]
After Greenpeace activists attempted to scale the [[Prirazlomnoye field|Prirazlomnaya]] [[drilling platform]] on 18 September 2013, as part of a protest against Arctic oil production, Russian authorities seized the Greenpeace ship the ''[[Arctic Sunrise]]'' in international waters in the Russian [[Exclusive Economic Zone]] on 19 September 2013, arrested the crew at gunpoint, towed the ship to Murmansk, and detained the crew of 28 activists and two freelance journalists. The [[ Investigative Committee of Russia ]] opened a criminal investigation, charging the activists initially with [[piracy]] and later with [[hooliganism]]. Since the ''Arctic Sunrise'' was flying the Dutch flag, the Netherlands filed a case at the [[International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea]] (ITLOS case 22) which argued (and obtained ruling) the release of the crew and ship until both parties can resolve the conflict. Russia ignored the ITLOS ruling, but eventually released the crew as part of a general amnesty adopted by the [[State Duma]] after two months of detention. The ''Arctic Sunrise'' itself was released from Russian detainment in June 2014.
==Background==
On 11 August 2013, the [[Greenpeace]] ship ''[[Arctic Sunrise]]'' left the Norwegian port of [[Kirkenes]] to begin a month-long expedition in the Arctic to protest against oil exploration in Arctic waters.<ref name="Into the Arctic">Rawer, Daniel. [http://intothearctic.gp/en/#/map/stories/confronting_arctic_oil/day-13/06-02pm "http://intothearctic.gp/en/#/map/stories/confronting_arctic_oil/day-13/06-02pm"], [[Greenpeace]], 12 August 2013.</ref> The ''Arctic Sunrise'' sailed into the [[Barents Sea]] and was then refused permission three times by the Russian authorities to enter the [[Northern Sea Route]] although the refusal is in violation of international law including the right to freedom of navigation.<ref name="Greenpeace Press Release">[http://www.greenpeace.org.uk/media/press-releases/russia-shuts-greenpeace-out-arctic-sea-route-stifles-criticism-oil-industry-20130821 "Russia shuts Greenpeace out of Arctic Sea route, stifles criticism of oil industry"], [[Greenpeace]], 21 August 2013.</ref><ref name="Greenpeace Australia">Rashini Suriyaarachchi [http://www.greenpeace.org.au/blog/defending-the-arctic-even-as-russia-threatens-to-use-force/ "Defending the Arctic even as Russia threatens to use force"], [[Greenpeace]], 26 August 2013.</ref> On 23 August, Greenpeace ignored Russia's ban to protest state oil company Rosneft’s operations in the Arctic and entered the international waters of the [[Kara Sea]].<ref name="Rianovosti">[http://en.ria.ru/russia/20130824/182942111.html "Greenpeace Ship Sails to Arctic Kara Sea Despite Ban"], [[RIA Novosti]], 24 August 2013.</ref> On 26 August, the ''Arctic Sunrise'' left the Northern Sea Route, after the Russian coastguard boarded the boat and threatened to use force if they would not leave the international waters of the Kara sea.<ref name="Newswire">[http://ens-newswire.com/2013/08/26/russians-force-greenpeace-ship-to-leave-kara-sea/ "Russians Force Greenpeace Ship to Leave Kara Sea"], ''[[Environment News Service]]'', 26 August 2013.</ref>
==Prirazlomnaya protest, and seizure of the ''Arctic Sunrise'' and crew== On 18 September 2013, four [[RHIB]] inflatables were launched from the ''Arctic Sunrise'' from its position in the [[Pechora Sea]].<ref name="Moscow Times">[http://www.themoscowtimes.com/special/environment/eng/greenpeace-storms-prirazlomnaya-platform-in-arctic.html "Greenpeace Storms Prirazlomnaya Platform in Arctic"], ''[[The Moscow Times]]''.</ref> The RHIBs carried [[Greenpeace]] activists and crew members towards [[Gazprom]]'s [[Prirazlomnaya]] [[drilling platform]]. At the time of the action, the ''Arctic Sunrise'' tweeted "We're going to try and stop the drilling.",<ref name="Twitter">[https://twitter.com/gp_sunrise/status/380127561423925248 ''Arctic Sunrise'' Twitter feed], 18 September 2013 ''Twitter''.</ref> although subsequently Greenpeace have stated that their aim was to hang banners on the oil rig to call for an end to Arctic drilling.<ref name="Ruptly">[http://rt.com/news/greenpeace-arctic-platform-shots-034/ "Warning shots fired as Russia detains Greenpeace activists at Arctic oil rig"], Warning shots fired as Russia detains Greenpeace activists at Arctic oil rig, 18 September 2013 ''[[Ruptly]]''.</ref> Two activists managed to attach themselves to the platform and attempted to climb, despite being blasted with water, while another activist tried unsuccessfully to become attached to the platform. The Russian coastguard fired warning shots from [[AK-74]] rifles and four warning shots from a cannon on board the ''Ladoga'' coastal patrol vessel.<ref name="Ruptly" /> The two activists were removed from the platform and held on board the coastguard vessel, although it was unclear whether or not they had been placed under arrest.<ref name="BBC">[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-24141667 "Greenpeace Activists Being Held Without Charge By Russia" Greenpeace assails oil rig in Russian Arctic], BBC News, 18 September 2013.</ref><ref name="Scoop">[http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/WO1309/S00319/greenpeace-activists-being-held-without-charge-by-russia.htm "Greenpeace Activists Being Held Without Charge By Russia"], ''[[Scoop Independent News]]'', 20 September 2013.</ref><ref name="ITLOS">[http://www.itlos.org/fileadmin/itlos/documents/cases/case_no.22/Response_questions_en.pdf "Answers to questions posed by the Tribunal"], 7 November 2013'' [[International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea]]''.</ref>
On 19 September, the day after the Prirazlomnaya protest, the Russian authorities forcibly took control of the ''Arctic Sunrise'', which was boarded from a helicopter by fifteen [[Federal Security Service]] officers in balaclavas, armed with guns and knives.<ref name="Independent">Brown, Jonathan [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/russia-arrests-30-environmental-activists-during-arctic-protest-8830165.html "Russia arrests 30 environmental activists during Arctic protest"], 20 September 2013'' [[The Independent]]''.</ref> At the time of the boarding, the ''Arctic Sunrise'' was in Russia's [[Exclusive Economic Zone]] but not within the safety zone around the oil rig, and permission was not sought to board it from the ''Arctic Sunrise'''s [[flag state]], the Netherlands.<ref name="ITLOS" /> The captain was separated from the crew and brutally beaten, while other crew members and activists were held in the mess room.<ref name="Telegraph">Wilson, Steve [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/russia/10322223/Russia-seizes-Greenpeace-ship-after-Arctic-rig-protest.html "Russia ''seizes'' Greenpeace ship after Arctic rig protest"], 20 September 2013'' [[The Daily Telegraph]]''.</ref> It is alleged that crew members and activists were brutally beaten, punched and kicked during the forced boarding.<ref name="Independent"/>
The ''Arctic Sunrise'' was towed to the port of [[Murmansk]]. All of the 30 people on board were taken to a detention facility where they were brutally beaten and interrogated. In early October, the [[Leninsky Administrative Okrug, Murmansk|Leninsky]] [[Judiciary of Russia#District courts|District Court]] in Murmansk issued a warrant to arrest all 30 people.<ref name="en.itar-tass.com">{{cite news|title=Arrested Greenpeace activists to be transferred to St. Petersburg by November 12|agency=[[Information Telegraph Agency of Russia|ITAR-TASS]]|date=11 November 2013|url=http://en.itar-tass.com/russia/705589}}</ref> 22 were put in custody for two months pending an investigation and the other eight were detained for three days pending a new hearing. They were under investigation for [[piracy]], which in Russia carries a maximum jail sentence of 15 years.<ref name="Rianovosti"/><ref name="ABC News">Vasilyeva, Nataliya. [[Associated Press]], [http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/greenpeace-appeal-activists-jailing-russia-20399080?singlePage=true Greenpeace To Appeal Activists’ Jailing In Russia"], [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] News, 27 September 2013.</ref><ref name="BBC News">[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-24298287 "Greenpeace to appeal over activists held in Russia"], [[BBC]] News, 27 September 2013.</ref> <!-- No charges have been brought against any of the activists. Russian authorities are considering whether to charge them with piracy, among other offenses. --> On 23 October the charge of piracy was dropped and replaced by a charge for aggravated [[hooliganism]] with a maximum sentence of seven years.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sledcom.ru/actual/361187/ |title=Следствием переквалифицированы действия нападавших на платформу "Приразломная" |publisher=Sledcom.ru |date=23 October 2013 |accessdate=26 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131026022408/http://sledcom.ru/actual/361187/ |archivedate=26 October 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Steve |last=Rosenberg |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-24645300 |title=Russia drops piracy charges against Greenpeace group |publisher=BBC News |date=23 October 2013 |accessdate=26 October 2013}}</ref> After they were transferred to [[Saint Petersburg]] on 12 November,<ref name="en.itar-tass.com"/> the [[Kalininsky District, Saint Petersburg|Kalininsky]] and [[Primorsky District, Saint Petersburg|Primorsky]] district courts released most of the people on bail,<ref>{{cite news|title=First Arctic Sunrise activist granted bail on Friday|date=22 November 2013|work=[[Voice of Russia]]|url=http://voiceofrussia.com/news/2013_11_22/First-Arctic-Sunrise-activist-granted-bail-on-Friday-2667/}}</ref> and the Murmansk [[Judiciary of Russia#Regional courts|Regional Court]] rejected an appeal against the arrests on 21 November.<ref>{{citation|title=Murmansk court rejects appeal over arrest of ship Arctic Sunrise|date=21 November 2013|publisher=Greenpeace|url=http://www.greenpeace.org/international/en/press/releases/Murmansk-court-rejects-appeal-over-arrest-of-ship-Arctic-Sunrise/}}</ref>
According to [[Phil Radford]], Executive Director of Greenpeace in the U.S. at the time, the reaction of the [[Coast Guard (Russia)|Russian coast guard]] and courts were the "stiffest response that Greenpeace has encountered from a government since the [[Sinking of the Rainbow Warrior|bombing]] of the ''[[Rainbow Warrior (1955)|Rainbow Warrior]]'' in 1985."<ref name="Washington Post">{{cite news |first = Kathy |last=Lally |first2=Will |last2=Englund|url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/us-greenpeace-captain-jailed-in-russia/2013/09/27/5e4f6968-2788-11e3-9372-92606241ae9c_story.html |title= U.S. Greenpeace captain jailed in Russia |work = The Washington Post| date=27 September 2013}}</ref>
==Detainees== The detainees have been christened the "Arctic 30" by Greenpeace<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.greenpeace.org/international/en/campaigns/climate-change/arctic-impacts/Peace-Dove/Arctic-30/| title=Free the Arctic 30| publisher=Greenpeace International| accessdate= 25 November 2013}}</ref> and the press.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2013/nov/20/british-greenpeace-activist-alexandra-harris-freed-bail| author=Shaun Walker and James Meikle| title=Three Arctic 30 Britons freed on bail by Russian court| work=The Guardian| date=20 November 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/arctic-30-british-greenpeace-activist-2837500| author=Steve Robson| title=Arctic 30: First British Greenpeace activist arrested in Russia given bail| publisher=The Mirror| date=22 November 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/greenpeace-arctic-30-britons-anthony-perrett-and-kieron-bryan-are-released-on-bail-8956198.html| author=Heather Saul| title=Greenpeace Arctic 30: Britons Anthony Perrett and Kieron Bryan are released on bail| work=The Independent| date=22 November 2013| location=London}}</ref> They include:
Crew by nationality: *US: Captain [[Peter Willcox|Peter Henry Willcox]]<ref name="BBC News"/> *Argentina: Second mate Miguel Hernán Pérez Orsi *Australia: Radio operator Colin Russell *Brazil: Deckhand Ana Paula Alminhana Maciel *Canada: Bosun Alexandre Paul, first mate Paul D Ruzycki *Denmark: Third mate Anne Mie Roer Jensen *France: Deckhand Francesco Pisanu *Italy: Deckhand Cristian D'Alessandro *Netherlands: Chief engineer Mannes Ubels *New Zealand: Boat mechanic Jonathan Beauchamp, electrician David John Haussmann *Turkey: Volunteer assistant cook Gizem Akhan *UK: Communications officer Alexandra Hazel Harris, 2nd engineer Iain Rogers *Ukraine: Cook Ruslan Yakushev <ref>{{cite web|url=http://rt.com/news/greenpeace-charged-piracy-russia-701/ |title=Russia charges all Arctic Sunrise Greenpeace activists with piracy over oil rig protest |publisher=RT News |date=3 October 2013 |accessdate=26 October 2013}}</ref>
Activists by nationality: *Argentina: Activist Camila Speziale *Finland: Activist Sini Saarela *Netherlands: Campaigner Faiza Oulahsen *Poland: Activist Tomasz Dziemianczuk *Russia: Spokesman Roman Dolgov, Dr Yekaterina Zaspa, press officer Andrei Allahverdov *Sweden: Campaigner Dima Litvinov *Switzerland: Activist Marco Weber *UK: logistics co-ordinator Frank Hewetson, activist Anthony Perrett, activist Philip Ball
Non-activists and journalists by nationality: *UK: Videographer and journalist Kieron Bryan *Russia: Photographer Denis Sinyakov
==Responses== [[File:Rally in support of arrested photographer from Arctic Sunrise Denis Sinyakov.jpg|thumb|Rally in support of arrested photographer Denis Sinyakov]]
One of the jailed people is the award-winning Russian photographer Denis Sinyakov, whose jailing led to protests by the Russian Union of Journalists and the international group [[Reporters Without Borders]].<ref name="Rianovosti"/> According to Alexei Simonov, head of [[Glasnost Defense Foundation]], a Moscow-based rights group, Sinyakov was only covering the actions of Greenpeace activists in the Barents Sea and has nothing to do with the group's agenda, saying: "The authorities violated all norms and laws by keeping Sinyakov in prison ... I must say it again and again that Russian justice system is designed by the Kremlin not to look for real culprits to be punished but to punish and scare those who don't suit the authorities."<ref name="Los Angeles Times">Loiko, Sergei L. [http://www.latimes.com/world/worldnow/la-fg-wn-greenpeace-activists-under-arrest-20130926,0,4020565.story "Greenpeace activists, Moscow photographer placed under arrest"], ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', 26 September 2013.</ref> Sinyakov posted on his Facebook account an image of a hooded Russian coast guardsman pointing a handgun at the boat. When the first two activists were detained, Sinyakov wrote: "I call upon you to join the struggle for freeing these activists, who sincerely see Arctic exploration as malignant." He was subsequently detained.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}} The top trans-Atlantic security and rights group, the [[Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe]], also demanded Sinyakov's immediate release. Several Russian media outlets, including the lenta.ru site and a private but Kremlin-friendly{{citation needed|date=October 2013}} national TV station, [[NTV (Russia)|NTV]], took all pictures off their websites in a show of solidarity with the jailed photographer.<ref name="BBC News"/> In Paris, a few dozen Greenpeace activists protested in front of the Russian Embassy on 27 September, waving banners with images of the incarcerated activists and the word "FREE" written over them. Up to 22 November, Russian court released all but one of the Greenpeace campaigners against bail (paid by Greenpeace) with the condition the campaigners could not leave Russia.<ref>[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/asia/2013/11/russia-frees-greenpeace-activists-bail-201311229514726461.html]</ref>
As [[flag state]] for the ''Arctic Sunrise'', the Netherlands asked for immediate release of the ship and shipmates to Dutch authorities. The Dutch government argues that since the ship was outside Russian [[territorial waters]] and outside the (500 meter) safety zone around the oil rig, it was in open sea, and hence outside Russian sovereign rights and jurisdiction. According to nautical law any actions against a ship in open sea can only be conducted after agreement with the flag state. Hence the Dutch take the position the capture of the ''Arctic Sunrise'' by Russia was not legal. After Russia did not release the ship the Netherlands filed a formal case to the [[International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea]] 21. October to order Russia to release a Greenpeace ship and the activists who were on board.<ref>{{cite news|agency=Associated Press |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/netherlands-asks-sea-law-tribunal-to-order-russia-to-release-greenpeace-ship-and-activists/2013/10/21/e68980dc-3ab3-11e3-b0e7-716179a2c2c7_story.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20131022090132/http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/netherlands-asks-sea-law-tribunal-to-order-russia-to-release-greenpeace-ship-and-activists/2013/10/21/e68980dc-3ab3-11e3-b0e7-716179a2c2c7_story.html |archive-date=22 October 2013 |title=Netherlands asks sea law tribunal to order Russia to release Greenpeace ship and activists |work=The Washington Post |date=21 October 2013 |accessdate=26 October 2013 |deadurl=yes}} </ref> However, Russian government announced that it will not participate in the hearings, pointing out that back in 1997, when it ratified the [[United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea]], it refused to acknowledge the settlement procedures, which result in mandatory decisions in disputes over sovereign rights and jurisdictions.<ref>[http://rt.com/news/greenpeace-arctic-sunrise-court-617/ Arctic Sunrise case: Russia to boycott intl maritime tribunal over Greenpeace arrests] 23 October 2013 [[RT (TV network)|RT]]</ref>
New Zealand Prime Minister [[John Key]] has raised the issue with Russian President [[Vladimir Putin]], but says the Russian judicial process must run its course.<ref>[http://www.3news.co.nz/Key-raises-Greenpeace-NZers-with-Putin/tabid/417/articleID/316451/Default.aspx Key raises Greenpeace NZers with Putin]. ''3 News NZ''. 9 October 2013.</ref>
Eleven Nobel prize-winners have written to [[Vladimir Putin]] asking the Russian president to drop charges against Greenpeace activists and journalists.<ref>BBC: [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-24570492 Nobel laureates urge Putin to free Greenpeace activists], 17 October 2013</ref>
Six men broke in Greenpeace office in [[Murmansk]] and stole materials.<ref>[http://yle.fi/uutiset/greenpeace_murmanskin_toimistoon_murtauduttu/6889654 Greenpeace: Murmanskin toimistoon murtauduttu] yle 18 October 2013 {{fi}}</ref>{{relevance-inline|date=October 2013}}
===Legal cases against Russia===
On 22 November 2013 the [[International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea]] ruled that the campaigners and the ship should be immediately released, and should be allowed to leave the country, against a bail of 3.5 Million Euro.<ref>[http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/5c7cea3c-5386-11e3-9250-00144feabdc0.html#axzz2lgOoEQFY]</ref> On 14 August 2015 the international [[Permanent Court of Arbitration]] unanimously ruled that Russia had acted in breach of the [[UN Convention on the Law of the Sea]] and has to compensate the Dutch government (flag state of the ship) for damages to the ship. <ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34045493]</ref> The tribunal ruled that actions of Greenpeace could not be labelled as piracy or hooliganism; reasons Russia had given for capturing the ship. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/federal-politics/political-news/russian-arrest-of-greenpeace-arctic-30-activists-illegal-tribunal-says-20150825-gj79xr.html|title=Court orders Russia to pay compensation for Greenpeace ship seizure|date=2015-08-25|access-date=2017-11-05|publisher=[[Reuters]]}}</ref> Russia, a partner of the permanent court of arbitration, responded by stating it does not recognize the authority of the court in this case.<ref>http://uk.reuters.com/article/2015/08/25/uk-netherlands-russia-greenpeace-idUKKCN0QU0MA20150825</ref>
===Greenpeace announcements === [[File:Arctic 30 Berlin 041113 03.jpg|thumb|Vigil for the release of the Arctic 30 in front of the Russian embassy in Berlin]]
According to Greenpeace, charges of [[piracy]] against peaceful activists have no merit in international law. Greenpeace rejected the suggestion of [[Prohibition of drugs|illegal drugs]] on the ''Arctic Sunrise''. Certain [[pharmaceutical drug]]s are kept in a safe. The Russian authorities broke the safe after they took the vessel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greenpeace.org/international/en/news/features/Greenpeace-responds-to-allegations-by-Russian-authorities/ |title=Greenpeace International responds to allegations from Russian authorities |publisher=Greenpeace |date=10 October 2013 |accessdate=26 October 2013}}</ref>
[[Phil Radford]], executive director of Greenpeace USA, argues that the arrest of the Arctic 30 is the stiffest response that [[Greenpeace]] has encountered from a government since the bombing of the Rainbow Warrior by the French secret service in 1985.<ref name="Washington Post"/>
[[Greenpeace]] activists continue to call for governments to save the arctic, the original motivation for the protest.
According to Dutch Greenpeace members, the condition of the Greenpeace ship worsened during its stay in Murmansk, as the Russian officials are not taking proper care of the vessel.<ref name="theguardian1">[https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2013/oct/17/greenpeace-activists-warn-arctic-sunrise-risk Greenpeace activist arrested in Russia raises alarm over Arctic Sunrise ship] 17 October 2013 [[The Guardian]]</ref>
===International reaction === 11 [[List of Nobel Peace Prize laureates|Nobel peace laureates]] wrote to Putin, calling on him to drop the "excessive" charges of piracy: * South African Bishop [[Desmond Tutu]] * Northern Irish peace campaigner [[Betty Williams (Nobel laureate)|Betty Williams]] * Former President of Costa Rica, [[Oscar Arias Sanchez]] * US peace campaigner [[Jody Williams]] * Liberian peace campaigner [[Leymah Gbowee]] * Yemeni peace campaigner [[Tawakkol Karman]] * Guatemalan social reformist [[Rigoberta Menchú Tum]] * Northern Irish peace activist [[Mairead Maguire]] * Iranian lawyer and former judge [[Shirin Ebadi]] * Former President of East Timor [[Jose Ramos Horta]] * Argentine community organiser [[Adolfo Perez Esquivel]]<ref name="theguardian1"/><ref>[http://www.greenpeace.org/international/en/press/releases/Eleven-Nobel-Peace-Prize-winners-write-to-Russian-President-Vladimir-Putin-over-Greenpeace-case/ Eleven Nobel Peace Prize winners write to Russian President Vladimir Putin over Greenpeace case] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131017220813/http://www.greenpeace.org/international/en/press/releases/Eleven-Nobel-Peace-Prize-winners-write-to-Russian-President-Vladimir-Putin-over-Greenpeace-case/ |date=17 October 2013 }} Greenpeace</ref>
German chancellor [[Angela Merkel]] expressed concerns about the arrest of the Greenpeace activists to [[Vladimir Putin]], and urged a swift resolution of the case.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2013/oct/17/angela-merkel-putin-greenpeace-arctic-30 Angela Merkel pressures Putin over Arctic 30 arrests] 17 October 2013 [[The Guardian]]</ref>
[[William Hague]], the foreign secretary UK, has been negotiating with Russian ministers over the fate of the six British nationals involved.<ref name=Guardian17oct>[https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2013/oct/17/uk-hub-arctic-oil-exploration-greenpeace UK aims to become hub for Arctic oil exploration] 17 October 2013 [[The Guardian]]</ref>
According to [[Julia Marton-Lefevre]], the [[International Union for the Conservation of Nature]] oil and gas exploring in the Arctic would have drastic consequences and the world should find low-carbon sources of energy.<ref name=Guardian17oct/>
[[Damon Albarn]] of [[Blur (band)|Blur]] showed a poster of Frank Hewetson during the band's concert in Santiago, Chile, on 7 November, asking for him to be freed.
==Dropping of charges under amnesty law== On 24 December 2013, it was announced that the first of the detainees, Anthony Perrett, had been freed under the amnesty law passed by the Russian parliament, and that more would be freed and the charges against them dropped.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-25504016 |title=Russia drops first Greenpeace Arctic 30 case |publisher=BBC News |date=24 December 2013 }}</ref>

The '''Honda Battle of the Bands''' (sometimes abbreviated '''The Honda''' or '''HBOB''') is an annual [[marching band]] exhibition in the [[United States]] which features performances by bands from [[historically black colleges and universities]] (HBCUs). Sponsored by the [[Honda|American Honda Motor Company]], the '''Invitational Showcase''' takes place in the [[Mercedes-Benz Stadium]] in [[Atlanta|Atlanta, Georgia]] in late January.
The '''Honda Battle of the Bands Celebration Tour''' takes place between the months of September and November at regular season [[college football|football]] games, although Honda Battle of the Bands (and its abbreviations) is often intended to refer only to the invitational showcase, which first took place in 2003. Seemingly contradictory to the name, Honda's "battle" is not a competition in the traditional sense; that is, no winner is crowned during the event. Rather, the bands compete for the favor of the audience, each other, and the greater community. The 2016 event had a nearly sold out crowd with 63,000+ fans and spectators in attendance.<ref>http://www.cbs8.com/story/31099788/63000-celebrate-hbcu-marching-band-excellence-at-honda-battle-of-the-bands-for-the-ages</ref>
== Participation == {| class="toccolours collapsible autocollapse" cellspacing="3px" style="width: 24em; float: right; margin: 0 0 1em 1em; text-align:left;" |The fictitious [[Black Entertainment Television|BET]] Big Southern Classic from the 2002 film ''[[Drumline (film)|Drumline]]'' was based on the HBOB. |} The Honda Battle of the Bands program includes two components — the Voting Process, which runs September through October, and the "Honda Battle of the Bands Invitational Showcase".
Voting: The first band will be selected by popular vote (i.e. the top overall vote-getter will be selected regardless of category). The next three bands will be selected, one from each category by a weighted vote of 1/3 from institution president, band director and online opinion poll from category I, II and III. The categories being 128 instruments or less, 129 instruments up to 160 and 161 or more. This count is total instrument count, no auxiliaries, drum majors, etc. but will include percussion. [[File:Mercedes Benz Stadium time lapse capture 2017-08-13.jpg|thumb|240px|Mercedez-Benz Stadium]] :a. Online Opinion Poll at hondabattleofthebands.com -- 1/3 weight :b. Band Directors’ Votes -- 1/3 weight :c. Presidents’ Votes -- 1/3 weight
Note: Presidents and Band Directors are not permitted to vote for their own institutions. [[American Honda Motor Company|American Honda]] and Urban Sports & Entertainment Group will select the final four bands based on, but not limited to: :a. Showmanship :b. Social Media Buzz :c. Years of previous participation in the Celebration Tour
Once all the votes are tallied, a total of '''8 bands''' are invited to perform their carefully choreographed, halftime time routines in front of 50,000+ fans.
== History == Started in 2003, the Honda Battle of the Bands was created to celebrate, support and recognize the excellence of Black college marching bands and the unique academic experience offered by Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs). Honda annually awards more than $205,000 in grants to participating marching bands during the program period and facilitates a HBCU recruitment fair preceding the band showcase.
